articles.headline: Maybe It’s Time to Change Credit Cards
articles.snippet: Credit cards are raising rates and fees as new federal rules take effect. But if your credit is good, you can always switch card issuers.
articles.abstract: Credit cards are raising rates and fees as new federal rules take effect. But if your credit is good, you can always switch card issuers.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re like most credit card customers, you’ve gotten notes from your bank in recent weeks.

articles.headline: D.I.Y. Chains Adjust to Smaller Projects
articles.snippet: Home Depot and Lowe’s are positioning for the wave of small, do-it-yourself repair and maintenance projects as sales suffer.
articles.abstract: Home Depot and Lowe’s are positioning for the wave of small, do-it-yourself repair and maintenance projects as sales suffer.
articles.lead_paragraph: In prerecession days, home improvement projects were usually grand, expensive overhauls of kitchens and bathrooms.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Rosenbloom and Karen Ann Cullotta

articles.headline: Credit Crisis Is a Big Draw for Finance Museum
articles.snippet: At the Museum of American Finance, the “greed, recklessness and arrogance” of Wall Street is on display.
articles.abstract: At the Museum of American Finance, the “greed, recklessness and arrogance” of Wall Street is on display.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Museum of American Finance was faced with an awkward situation recently: some of the corporate sponsors of the museum  dedicated to glories of free markets  had, well, failed.

articles.headline: Brief Relief, but No Cure for Carmakers From Clunker Plan
articles.snippet: The cash-for-clunkers program provided a short-term bonanza for automakers but will not have a lasting effect on the industry’s worst sales slump in 25 years.
articles.abstract: The cash-for-clunkers program provided a short-term bonanza for automakers but will not have a lasting effect on the industry’s worst sales slump in 25 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The government’s cash-for-clunkers program provided a short-term bonanza for automakers but will not have a lasting effect on an industry mired in its worst sales slump in 25 years.

articles.headline: Afghan Election Poses New Tests for Washington
articles.snippet: Rather than demonstrate stability justifying an expanded U.S. commitment in Afghanistan, the Afghan presidential election underscored the challenges that remain.
articles.abstract: Rather than demonstrate stability justifying an expanded U.S. commitment in Afghanistan, the Afghan presidential election underscored the challenges that remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Obama administration officials hoped the Afghan election would demonstrate that eight years after the American invasion, the country was stable enough to justify an expanded commitment of money and troops from an increasingly skeptical American public.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Carlotta Gall

articles.headline: U.S. Shifts, Giving Detainee Names to the Red Cross
articles.snippet: In a reversal of Pentagon policy, the military is notifying the International Committee of the Red Cross of the identities of militants who were held in secret at camps.
articles.abstract: In a reversal of Pentagon policy, the military is notifying the International Committee of the Red Cross of the identities of militants who were held in secret at camps.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In a reversal of Pentagon policy, the military for the first time is notifying the International Committee of the Red Cross of the identities of militants who were being held in secret at a camp in Iraq and another in Afghanistan run by United States Special Operations forces, according to three military officials.

articles.headline: A Cul-de-Sac of Lost Dreams, and New Ones
articles.snippet: The housing bust fundamentally changed a street with eight houses in Southern California.
articles.abstract: The housing bust fundamentally changed a street with eight houses in Southern California.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORENO VALLEY, Calif.  The rose bushes are back in bloom on Beth Court, but the lawns on the block remain parched and browning, reminders of the absent families who once tended to them.

articles.headline: Debating How Much Weed Killer Is Safe in Your Water Glass
articles.snippet: New research suggests that atrazine may be dangerous at lower concentrations than previously thought, particularly for fetuses.
articles.abstract: New research suggests that atrazine may be dangerous at lower concentrations than previously thought, particularly for fetuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, farmers, lawn care workers and professional green thumbs have relied on the popular weed killer atrazine to protect their crops, golf courses and manicured lawns.

articles.headline: What the Stress Tests Didn’t Predict
articles.snippet: An analysis shows that the number of financially sound banks is declining and that the ranks of troubled institutions are growing.
articles.abstract: An analysis shows that the number of financially sound banks is declining and that the ranks of troubled institutions are growing.
articles.lead_paragraph: FINANCIAL stocks have more than doubled from their March 2009 lows. And with autumn  generally a rocky season for the markets  fast approaching, it’s a good time for a reality check on the banking sector. The goal: to determine whether fundamentals in the industry support the rocket-fueled surge in bank shares.

articles.headline: Turning Music Into Dollars at Sony/ATV
articles.snippet: The chief executive of Sony/ATV sees promise in the reuse of songs on TV, in movies and in greeting cards.
articles.abstract: The chief executive of Sony/ATV sees promise in the reuse of songs on TV, in movies and in greeting cards.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARTY BANDIER, 68, chief executive of the music publishing giant Sony/ATV, is leaning back, hands locked across his midsection, as he takes stock of Mike Posner, a 21-year-old college student sitting in front of him in a black T-shirt and black jeans. Mr. Bandier is deciding whether the time has come to cut a deal with him.

articles.headline: On to Plan B: Starting a Business
articles.snippet: With the jobless rate hovering near double digits, some corporate refugees are taking the entrepreneurial route by necessity.
articles.abstract: With the jobless rate hovering near double digits, some corporate refugees are taking the entrepreneurial route by necessity.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALL them accidental entrepreneurs, unintended entrepreneurs or forced entrepreneurs. A year and a half into the Great Recession, with the jobless rate hovering near double digits, corporate refugees like Lisa Marie Grillos of San Francisco are trying to fend for themselves.

articles.headline: Marines Fight Taliban With Little Aid From Afghans
articles.snippet: Lack of support from Afghan officials has hindered American efforts to win over residents in a region where the Taliban remain a menacing presence.
articles.abstract: Lack of support from Afghan officials has hindered American efforts to win over residents in a region where the Taliban remain a menacing presence.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHAN NESHIN, Afghanistan  American Marines secured this desolate village in southern Afghanistan nearly two months ago, and last week they were fortifying bases, on duty at checkpoints and patrolling in full body armor in 120-degree heat. Despite those efforts, only a few hundred Afghans were persuaded to come out here and vote for president on Thursday.

articles.headline: Obama’s Team Is Lacking Most of Its Top Players
articles.snippet: President Obama has filled just 43 percent of more than 500 policymaking positions requiring confirmation.
articles.abstract: President Obama has filled just 43 percent of more than 500 policymaking positions requiring confirmation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As President Obama tries to turn around a summer of setbacks, he finds himself still without most of his own team. Seven months into his presidency, fewer than half of his top appointees are in place advancing his agenda.

articles.headline: The Readers Are Over 40. (Don’t Tell Advertisers.)
articles.snippet: While More magazine proudly serves women over 40, it is trying to lower its average reader age. Advertisers would like to reach younger consumers.
articles.abstract: While More magazine proudly serves women over 40, it is trying to lower its average reader age. Advertisers would like to reach younger consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: More, the magazine from the publisher Meredith for women over 40, ran an article in its most recent issue on how to seem younger. Among the advice: get your bikini line waxed, start text-messaging, and stop planning everything (the young people don’t bother with it at all).

articles.headline: Monocle: A Magazine, an Attitude
articles.snippet: Tyler Brûlé, an advertising executive and magazine editor, works with what he calls patrons to build up his travel publication.
articles.abstract: Tyler Brûlé, an advertising executive and magazine editor, works with what he calls patrons to build up his travel publication.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many publishers will refer to advertisers as business partners. Tyler Brûlé, the founder of Wallpaper magazine and editor in chief of Monocle, calls them “patrons of Monocle’s approach.”

articles.headline: Mining the Web for Feelings, Not Facts
articles.snippet: The universe of reviews, ratings and recommendations online open a tantalizing window on the collective consciousness.
articles.abstract: The universe of reviews, ratings and recommendations online open a tantalizing window on the collective consciousness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Computers may be good at crunching numbers, but can they crunch feelings?

articles.headline: Plain Talk From Judge Weighing Merrill Case
articles.snippet: Jed S. Rakoff, a United States District Court judge in Manhattan, is not one to rubber-stamp administrative decisions.
articles.abstract: Jed S. Rakoff, a United States District Court judge in Manhattan, is not one to rubber-stamp administrative decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jed S. Rakoff, a United States District Court judge in Manhattan, is not one to rubber-stamp administrative decisions.

articles.headline: Asia’s Recovery Highlights China’s Ascendance
articles.snippet: Economists have long predicted that China would eventually surpass the U.S. in influence. That change may be arriving sooner than expected.
articles.abstract: Economists have long predicted that China would eventually surpass the U.S. in influence. That change may be arriving sooner than expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  In past global slowdowns, the United States invariably led the way out, followed by Europe and the rest of the world. But for the first time, the catalyst is coming from China and the rest of Asia, where resurgent economies are helping the still-shaky West recover from the deepest recession since World War II.

articles.headline: U.S. Military Says Its Force in Afghanistan Is Insufficient
articles.snippet: Despite the addition of 17,000 U.S. troops and extra security for the presidential election, the situation in Afghanistan is deteriorating.
articles.abstract: Despite the addition of 17,000 U.S. troops and extra security for the presidential election, the situation in Afghanistan is deteriorating.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGRAM, Afghanistan  American military commanders with the NATO mission in Afghanistan told President Obama’s chief envoy to the region this weekend that they did not have enough troops to do their job, pushed past their limit by Taliban rebels who operate across borders.

articles.headline: After 48 Years, Julia Child Has a Big Best Seller, Butter and All
articles.snippet: Almost 48 years after it was first published, “Mastering the Art of French Cooking” by Julia Child is finally topping the best-seller list.
articles.abstract: Almost 48 years after it was first published, “Mastering the Art of French Cooking” by Julia Child is finally topping the best-seller list.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost 48 years after it was first published, “Mastering the Art of French Cooking” by Julia Child is finally topping the best-seller list, bringing with it all the butter, salt and goose fat that home chefs had largely abandoned in the age of Lipitor.

articles.headline: With Dad Laid Off, Finding Ways to Hold On
articles.snippet: For longtime residents of a block in Moreno Valley, Calif., the recession has oddly helped family stability.
articles.abstract: For longtime residents of a block in Moreno Valley, Calif., the recession has oddly helped family stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORENO VALLEY, Calif.  Among the flotsam and jetsam that gather over the years in a home, there is now the random taillight behind the Winklers’ living room couch. And a 1967 Buick Riviera dashboard under the desk. When jobs are short and the savings account dwindles, selling spare parts on the Internet can help put braces in mouths, and pay a credit card bill or two.

articles.headline: The Man Who Sells America’s I.O.U.’s
articles.snippet: Van Zeck has been helping manage the government’s credit line since 1971. This year, he’s been a busy man.
articles.abstract: Van Zeck has been helping manage the government’s credit line since 1971. This year, he’s been a busy man.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The brightly illuminated room looks like mission control for a space flight. Seven people, wearing headphones, stare intently at computer screens. Three minutes before the deadline, a disembodied voice exclaims, “We have coverage.”

articles.headline: Arrest Over Software Illuminates Wall St. Secret
articles.snippet: Ultrafast stock trading relies upon computer programs that take years to develop and are closely guarded secrets.
articles.abstract: Ultrafast stock trading relies upon computer programs that take years to develop and are closely guarded secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Flying home to New Jersey from Chicago after the first two days at his new job, Sergey Aleynikov was prepared for the usual inconveniences: a bumpy ride, a late arrival.

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Report Advises Pursuing C.I.A. Abuse Cases
articles.snippet: The Justice Department has recommended reversing the Bush administration and reopening nearly a dozen prisoner-abuse cases, potentially exposing C.I.A. employees to prosecution.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department has recommended reversing the Bush administration and reopening nearly a dozen prisoner-abuse cases, potentially exposing C.I.A. employees to prosecution.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department’s ethics office has recommended reversing the Bush administration and reopening nearly a dozen prisoner-abuse cases, potentially exposing Central Intelligence Agency employees and contractors to prosecution for brutal treatment of terrorism suspects, according to a person officially briefed on the matter.
